00:12:57.240 | in terms of the last few years of AI,

00:13:03.800 | there are many ways to describe this,
00:13:05.800 | is more standard post-training.
00:13:08.040 | So this is things like instruction tuning,
00:13:10.200 | reinforce learning from human feedback,
00:13:11.880 | we'll get into some of these words,
00:13:13.720 | and this is what they did to create the DeepSeek V3 model.

00:14:11.760 | - Maybe we should also say
00:14:13.640 | the big two categories of training

00:14:18.640 | these umbrella terms that people use.
00:14:20.400 | So what is pre-training and what is post-training,
00:14:24.640 | and what are the different flavors of things
00:14:26.080 | underneath post-training umbrella?
00:14:27.760 | - Yeah, so pre-training,
00:14:29.040 | I'm using some of the same words
00:14:30.200 | to really get the message across,
00:14:31.720 | is you're doing what is called autoregressive prediction
00:14:34.240 | to predict the next token in a series of documents.
00:14:37.560 | This is done over standard practice
00:14:40.200 | is trillions of tokens.
00:14:41.800 | So this is a ton of data
00:14:44.240 | that is mostly scraped from the web.
00:14:46.920 | In some of DeepSeek's earlier papers,
00:14:49.120 | they talk about their training data
00:14:50.760 | being distilled for math.

00:14:56.600 | and that's a public access
00:14:58.600 | that anyone listening to this
00:14:59.640 | could go download data from the Common Crawl website.
00:15:01.960 | This is a crawler that is maintained publicly.
00:15:04.400 | Yes, other tech companies eventually shift
00:15:06.560 | to their own crawler,

00:15:09.800 | as most frontier labs do.
00:15:11.400 | But this sort of data is something
00:15:13.120 | that people can get started with,
00:15:14.800 | and you're just predicting text in a series of documents.
00:15:18.280 | This can be scaled to be very efficient,
00:15:23.280 | and there's a lot of numbers
00:15:24.520 | that are thrown around in AI training,
00:15:25.920 | like how many floating point operations or flops are used.
00:15:30.120 | And then you can also look at how many hours
00:15:31.920 | of these GPUs that are used.
00:15:35.280 | And it's largely one loss function
00:15:37.840 | taken to a very large amount of compute usage.
00:15:42.560 | You just set up really efficient systems.
00:15:45.000 | And then at the end of that,
00:15:46.280 | you have this base model,
00:15:47.880 | and pre-training is where there is a lot more
00:15:50.520 | of complexity in terms of how the process is emerging
00:15:55.520 | or evolving,
00:15:56.920 | and the different types of training losses
00:15:58.920 | that you will use.
00:15:59.960 | I think this is a lot of techniques
00:16:02.760 | grounded in the natural language processing literature.
00:16:05.960 | The oldest technique, which is still used today,
00:16:07.960 | is something called instruction tuning,
00:16:09.880 | or also known as supervised fine-tuning.
00:16:12.520 | These acronyms will be IFT or SFT.
00:16:15.840 | People really go back and forth throughout them,
00:16:18.000 | and I will probably do the same,
00:16:19.520 | which is where you add this formatting to the model
00:16:23.040 | where it knows to take a question
00:16:25.400 | that is like, "Explain the history
00:16:28.200 | of the Roman Empire to me,"
00:16:30.000 | or something, a sort of question you'll see on Reddit
00:16:32.840 | or Stack Overflow,
00:16:33.760 | and then the model will respond in a information-dense
00:16:37.400 | but presentable manner.
00:16:38.800 | The core of that formatting
00:16:39.800 | is in this instruction-tuning phase,
00:16:42.120 | and then there's two other categories of loss functions
00:16:45.400 | that are being used today.
00:16:47.240 | One I will classify as preference fine-tuning.
00:16:49.880 | Preference fine-tuning is a generalized term
00:16:52.240 | for what came out of reinforcement learning
00:16:54.240 | from human feedback, which is RLHF.
00:16:57.520 | This reinforcement learning from human feedback
00:17:00.240 | is credited as the technique
00:17:02.280 | that helped ChatGPT break through.
00:17:05.920 | It is a technique to make the responses
00:17:08.120 | that are nicely formatted, like these Reddit answers,
00:17:10.960 | more in tune with what a human would like to read.
00:17:14.320 | This is done by collecting pairwise preferences
00:17:16.640 | from actual humans out in the world to start,
00:17:19.480 | and now AIs are also labeling this data,
00:17:21.560 | and we'll get into those trade-offs.
00:17:23.680 | And you have this kind of contrastive loss function
00:17:26.840 | between a good answer and a bad answer,
00:17:28.560 | and the model learns to pick up these trends.
00:17:31.080 | There's different implementation ways.
00:17:33.280 | You have things called reward models.
00:17:35.040 | You could have direct alignment algorithms.
00:17:36.880 | There's a lot of really specific things you can do,
00:17:39.280 | but all of this is about fine-tuning to human preferences.
00:17:42.720 | And the final stage is much newer
00:17:44.960 | and will link to what is done in R1,
00:17:48.000 | and these reasoning models is,
00:17:50.480 | I think OpenAI is named for this.
00:17:52.160 | They had this new API in the fall,
00:17:53.440 | which they called the Reinforcement Fine-Tuning API.
00:17:57.360 | This is the idea that you use the techniques
00:17:59.320 | of reinforcement learning, which is a whole framework of AI.
00:18:02.840 | There's a deep literature here.
00:18:04.400 | To summarize, it's often known as trial and error learning,
00:18:08.040 | or the subfield of AI where you're trying
00:18:10.280 | to make sequential decisions
00:18:12.280 | in a certain potentially noisy environment.
00:18:15.960 | There's a lot of ways we could go down that,
00:18:18.160 | but fine-tuning language models
00:18:20.040 | where they can generate an answer,
00:18:21.960 | and then you check to see if the answer
00:18:23.960 | matches the true solution.
00:18:25.280 | For math or code, you have an exactly correct answer
00:18:28.880 | for math, you can have unit tests for code.
00:18:31.360 | And what we're doing is we are checking
00:18:33.040 | the language model's work,
00:18:34.360 | and we're giving it multiple opportunities
00:18:36.080 | on the same question to see if it is right.
00:18:38.160 | And if you keep doing this, the models can learn
00:18:40.080 | to improve in verifiable domains to a great extent.
00:18:44.280 | It works really well.
00:18:45.400 | It's a newer technique in the academic literature.
00:18:47.640 | It's been used at frontier labs in the US
00:18:50.200 | that don't share every detail for multiple years.
00:18:53.080 | So this is the idea of using reinforcement learning
00:18:56.600 | with language models, and it has been taking off,
00:18:58.960 | especially in this DeepSeq moment.
00:19:00.800 | - And we should say that there's a lot
00:19:01.920 | of exciting stuff going on, again, across the stack,
00:19:05.720 | but the post-training, probably this year,
00:19:07.840 | there's going to be a lot of interesting developments
00:19:09.520 | in the post-training, and we'll talk about it.
00:19:12.200 | I almost forgot to talk about the difference
00:19:14.400 | between DeepSeq v3 and R1 on the user experience side.
00:19:18.040 | So forget the technical stuff, forget all of that.
00:19:21.200 | Just people that don't know anything about AI,
00:19:23.520 | they show up, like, what's the actual experience?
00:19:25.920 | What's the use case for each one
00:19:27.640 | when they actually, like, type and talk to it?
00:19:29.840 | What is each good at and that kind of thing?
00:19:31.720 | - So let's start with DeepSeq v3 again.
00:19:33.760 | It's what more people would have tried something like it.
00:19:36.040 | You ask it a question.
00:19:37.560 | It'll start generating tokens very fast,
00:19:40.040 | and those tokens will look like
00:19:41.440 | a very human legible answer.
00:19:44.120 | It'll be some sort of markdown list.
00:19:46.840 | It might have formatting to help you draw
00:19:49.520 | to the core details in the answer,
00:19:52.280 | and it'll generate tens to hundreds of tokens.
00:19:55.280 | A token is normally a word for common words
00:19:58.640 | or a sub-word part in a longer word.
00:20:02.200 | And it'll look like a very high-quality
00:20:05.480 | Reddit or Stack Overflow answer.
00:20:06.840 | These models are really getting good at doing these
00:20:10.120 | across a wide variety of domains.
00:20:12.200 | Even things that, if you're an expert,
00:20:15.120 | things that are close to the fringe of knowledge,
00:20:17.120 | they will still be fairly good at.
00:20:19.600 | Cutting-edge AI topics that I do research on,
00:20:22.520 | these models are capable for study aid,
00:20:26.360 | and they're regularly updated.
00:20:28.360 | Where this changes is with the DeepSeq v1,
00:20:31.480 | what is called these reasoning models,
00:20:33.040 | is when you see tokens coming from these models to start,
00:20:36.560 | it will be a large chain-of-thought process.
00:20:40.600 | We'll get back to chain-of-thought in a second,
00:20:42.480 | which looks like a lot of tokens
00:20:44.800 | where the model is explaining the problem.
00:20:46.880 | The model will often break down the problem,
00:20:48.440 | and be like, "Okay, they asked me for this.
00:20:50.520 | Let's break down the problem.
00:20:51.960 | I'm going to need to do this."
00:20:53.560 | And you'll see all of this generating from the model.
00:20:55.720 | It'll come very fast in most user experiences.
00:20:57.960 | These APIs are very fast, so you'll see a lot of tokens.
00:21:00.640 | A lot of words show up really fast.
00:21:02.240 | It'll keep flowing on the screen,
00:21:03.840 | and this is all the reasoning process.
00:21:05.840 | And then eventually the model will change its tone in R1,
00:21:09.080 | and it'll write the answer,
00:21:10.160 | where it summarizes its reasoning process
00:21:13.400 | and writes a similar answer to the first types of model.
00:21:16.480 | But in DeepSeek's case,
00:21:18.040 | which is part of why this was so popular,
00:21:20.400 | even outside the AI community,
00:21:22.800 | is that you can see how the language model
00:21:24.840 | is breaking down problems.
00:21:26.880 | And then you get this answer on a technical side.
00:21:29.480 | They train the model to do this specifically,
00:21:31.560 | where they have a section, which is reasoning,
00:21:33.440 | and then it generates a special token,
00:21:34.920 | which is probably hidden from the user most of the time,
00:21:36.960 | which says, "Okay, I'm starting the answer."
00:21:38.800 | So the model is trained
00:21:40.040 | to do this two-stage process on its own.
00:21:42.840 | If you use a similar model in, say, OpenAI,
00:21:45.120 | OpenAI's user interface is trying to summarize this process
00:21:49.960 | for you nicely by kind of showing the sections
00:21:53.280 | that the model is doing,
00:21:54.720 | and it'll kind of click through.
00:21:55.960 | It'll say, "Breaking down the problem.
00:21:57.960 | "Making X calculation.
00:22:00.120 | "Cleaning the result."
00:22:01.160 | And then the answer will come for something like OpenAI.
00:22:03.800 | - Maybe it's useful here to go through, like,
00:22:05.480 | an example of a DeepSeek R1 reasoning.
00:22:09.080 | - Yeah, so if you're looking at the screen here,
00:22:12.080 | what you'll see is a screenshot
00:22:13.200 | of the DeepSeek chat app,
00:22:15.480 | and at the top is thought for 157 seconds
00:22:19.560 | with the dropdown arrow.
00:22:20.560 | Underneath that, if we were in an app that we were running,
00:22:23.040 | the dropdown arrow would have the reasoning.
00:22:24.800 | - So in this case, the specific question,
00:22:27.720 | which, you know, I'm philosophically/pothead-inclined,
00:22:31.440 | so this is asking DeepSeek R1
00:22:34.360 | for one truly novel insight about humans,
00:22:39.600 | and it reveals the reasoning,
00:22:41.400 | and basically the truly novel aspect
00:22:44.680 | is what's pushing the reasoning
00:22:46.600 | to constantly sort of demodel,
00:22:47.960 | asking itself, "Is this truly novel?"
00:22:49.600 | So it's actually challenging itself to be more novel,
00:22:52.600 | more counterintuitive,
00:22:53.920 | less cringe, I suppose.
00:22:57.440 | So some of the reasoning says,
00:22:59.120 | "This is just snapshots.
00:23:01.320 | "Alternatively, humans have a unique meta-emotion
00:23:03.960 | "where they feel emotions about their own emotions,
00:23:06.040 | "e.g. feeling guilty about being angry.

00:23:09.480 | "creates complex motivational drives
00:23:11.160 | "that don't exist in other animals.
00:23:13.240 | "The insight is that human emotions are nested."
00:23:15.560 | So it's reasoning through how humans feel emotions,
00:23:19.560 | it's reasoning about meta-emotions.
00:23:21.160 | - Gonna have pages and pages of this.
00:23:22.840 | It's almost too much to actually read,
00:23:24.400 | but it's nice to skim as it's coming.
00:23:26.440 | - It's a James Joyce-like stream of consciousness,
00:23:29.640 | and then it goes, "Wait, the user wants something
00:23:32.480 | "that's not seen anywhere else.
00:23:34.200 | "Let me dig deeper."
00:23:36.160 | And, "Consider the human ability
00:23:38.040 | "to hold contradictory beliefs simultaneously.
00:23:40.120 | "Cognitive dissonance is known,
00:23:41.720 | "but perhaps the function is to allow flexible adaptation."
00:23:45.600 | So on and so forth.
00:23:47.280 | I mean, that really captures the public imagination
00:23:50.360 | that, "Holy shit, this isn't..."
00:23:53.040 | I mean, intelligence/almost like an inkling of sentience,
00:23:59.720 | because you're thinking through,
00:24:02.200 | you're self-reflecting, you're deliberating.
00:24:04.480 | And the final result of that, after 157 seconds,
00:24:07.880 | is, "Humans instinctively convert selfish desires
00:24:12.480 | "into cooperative systems
00:24:13.680 | "by collectively pretending abstract rules,
00:24:16.080 | "money, laws, rights, are real.

00:24:21.840 | "where competition is secretly redirected
00:24:23.760 | "to benefit the group,
00:24:25.160 | "turning conflict into society's fuel."
00:24:27.920 | Pretty profound.
00:24:29.880 | I mean, you know.
00:24:31.800 | - This is a potential digression,
00:24:33.680 | but a lot of people have found
00:24:36.040 | that these reasoning models can sometimes produce
00:24:38.680 | much more eloquent text.
00:24:40.840 | That is a, at least, interesting example,
00:24:43.160 | I think, depending on how open-minded you are,
00:24:45.000 | you find language models interesting or not,
00:24:46.760 | and there's a spectrum there.
00:24:48.240 | - Well, I mean, it's some of the...
00:24:49.600 | We'll talk about different benchmarks and so on,
00:24:51.440 | but some is just a vibe.
00:24:53.360 | Like that, in itself, is a, let's say, quote, "fire tweet."
00:24:57.920 | - Yeah.
00:24:58.760 | - If I'm trying to produce something
00:25:01.520 | where people are like, "Oh shit, okay."
00:25:04.080 | So that's a chain of thought
00:25:04.920 | we'll probably return to more.
00:25:06.480 | How were they able to achieve such low cost
00:25:11.920 | on the training and the inference?
00:25:13.360 | Maybe you could talk the training first.
00:25:15.440 | - Yeah, so there's two main techniques
00:25:17.640 | that they implemented
00:25:19.360 | that are probably the majority of their efficiency,
00:25:23.040 | and then there's a lot of implementation details
00:25:25.120 | that maybe we'll gloss over or get into later
00:25:27.640 | that sort of contribute to it.
00:25:28.680 | But those two main things are,
00:25:30.920 | one is they went to a mixture of experts model,
00:25:34.360 | which we'll define in a second.
00:25:35.720 | And then the other thing is that they invented
00:25:37.520 | this new technique called MLA, latent attention.
00:25:40.520 | Both of these are big deals.
00:25:42.040 | Mixture of experts is something
00:25:43.400 | that's been in the literature for a handful of years.
00:25:46.080 | And OpenAI with GPT-4 was the first one
00:25:48.520 | to productize a mixture of experts model.
00:25:51.920 | And what this means is,
00:25:53.320 | when you look at the common models around
00:25:55.960 | that most people have been able to interact with
00:25:58.240 | that are open, right?
00:25:59.560 | Think Lama.
00:26:00.840 | Lama is a dense model,
00:26:02.680 | i.e. every single parameter or neuron is activated
00:26:06.760 | as you're going through the model
00:26:08.120 | for every single token you generate, right?
00:26:10.800 | Now, with a mixture of experts model,
00:26:12.920 | you don't do that, right?
00:26:13.800 | How does the human actually work, right?
00:26:15.680 | It's like, oh, well, my visual cortex is active
00:26:18.040 | when I'm thinking about, you know, vision tasks
00:26:20.080 | and like, you know, other things, right?
00:26:21.440 | My amygdala is when I'm scared, right?
00:26:24.000 | These different aspects of your brain
00:26:25.480 | are focused on different things.
00:26:26.920 | A mixture of experts model attempts
00:26:28.680 | to approximate this to some extent.
00:26:30.360 | It's nowhere close to what a brain architecture is,
00:26:32.640 | but different portions of the model activate, right?
00:26:35.600 | You'll have a set number of experts in the model
00:26:38.720 | and a set number that are activated each time.
00:26:40.840 | And this dramatically reduces both your training
00:26:43.080 | and inference costs.
00:26:44.040 | Because now you're, you know,
00:26:46.240 | if you think about the parameter count
00:26:48.080 | as the sort of total embedding space
00:26:50.000 | for all of this knowledge
00:26:51.040 | that you're compressing down during training,
00:26:53.320 | when you're embedding this data in,
00:26:56.360 | instead of having to activate every single parameter
00:26:59.120 | every single time you're training or running inference,
00:27:01.320 | now you can just activate a subset
00:27:03.360 | and the model will learn which expert to route to
00:27:06.160 | for different tasks.
00:27:07.480 | And so this is a humongous innovation
00:27:09.880 | in terms of, hey, I can continue to grow
00:27:12.160 | the total embedding space of parameters.
00:27:14.160 | And so DeepSeek's model is, you know,
00:27:15.720 | 600 something billion parameters, right?
00:27:18.200 | Relative to LLAMA405B, it's 405 billion parameters, right?
00:27:21.960 | Relative to LLAMA70B, it's 70 billion parameters, right?
00:27:24.360 | So this model technically has more embedding space
00:27:26.760 | for information, right?
00:27:28.200 | To compress all of the world's knowledge
00:27:29.840 | that's on the internet down,
00:27:31.240 | but at the same time,
00:27:32.640 | it is only activating around 37 billion of the parameters.
00:27:36.680 | So only 37 billion of these parameters
00:27:38.640 | actually need to be computed
00:27:40.080 | every single time you're training data
00:27:42.160 | or inferencing data out of it.
00:27:43.960 | And so versus, again, the LLAMA model,
00:27:46.440 | 70 billion parameters must be activated
00:27:48.240 | or 405 billion parameters must be activated.
00:27:50.440 | So you've dramatically reduced your compute cost
00:27:52.680 | when you're doing training and inference
00:27:54.760 | with this mixture of experts architecture.
00:27:57.320 | - Should we break down where it actually applies
00:27:59.480 | and go into the transformer?
00:28:01.120 | Is that useful?
00:28:01.960 | - Let's go, let's go into the transformer.
00:28:03.600 | - Okay, so the transformer is a thing
00:28:05.120 | that is talked about a lot
00:28:06.440 | and we will not cover every detail.
00:28:08.280 | Essentially, the transformer is built on repeated blocks
00:28:12.880 | of this attention mechanism
00:28:14.560 | and then a traditional dense, fully connected,
00:28:17.880 | multi-layer perception,
00:28:19.200 | whatever word you want to use
00:28:20.400 | for your normal neural network.
00:28:21.760 | And you alternate these blocks.
00:28:23.560 | There's other details.
00:28:24.880 | And where mixture of experts is applied
00:28:26.440 | is at this dense model.
00:28:28.240 | The dense model holds most of the weights
00:28:31.160 | if you count them in a transformer model.
00:28:33.840 | So you can get really big gains
00:28:35.480 | from those mixture of experts
00:28:37.160 | on parameter efficiency at training and inference
00:28:39.200 | because you get this efficiency
00:28:41.960 | by not activating all of these parameters.
00:28:44.120 | - We should also say that a transformer
00:28:46.720 | is a giant neural network.
00:28:48.680 | - Yeah.
00:28:49.520 | - And then there's for 15 years now,
00:28:51.960 | there's what's called the deep learning revolution.
00:28:54.440 | Network's gotten larger and larger.
00:28:56.280 | And at a certain point, the scaling laws appeared
00:28:58.720 | where people realized--
00:29:00.560 | - This is a scaling law shirt, by the way.
00:29:02.840 | - Representing scaling laws
00:29:04.960 | where it became more and more formalized
00:29:07.520 | that bigger is better across multiple dimensions
00:29:11.000 | of what bigger means.
00:29:12.160 | But these are all sort of neural networks
00:29:15.160 | we're talking about.
00:29:16.480 | And we're talking about different architectures
00:29:18.080 | of how to construct these neural networks
00:29:21.040 | such that the training and the inference on them
00:29:23.520 | is super efficient.
00:29:24.360 | - Yeah, every different type of model
00:29:25.720 | has a different scaling law for it,
00:29:27.960 | which is effectively for how much compute you put in,
00:29:30.840 | the architecture will get to different levels
00:29:34.440 | of performance at test tasks.
00:29:36.360 | And mixture of experts is one of the ones at training time,
00:29:39.240 | even if you don't consider the inference benefits,
00:29:41.280 | which are also big.
00:29:42.480 | At training time, your efficiency with your GPUs
00:29:44.920 | is dramatically improved by using this architecture
00:29:47.360 | if it is well implemented.
00:29:48.880 | So you can get effectively the same performance model
00:29:53.120 | and evaluation scores with numbers like 30% less compute.
00:29:57.440 | I think there's gonna be a wide variation
00:29:59.080 | depending on your implementation details and stuff.
00:30:01.480 | But it is just important to realize
00:30:03.840 | that this type of technical innovation
00:30:05.320 | is something that gives huge gains.
00:30:07.960 | And I expect most companies that are serving their models
00:30:11.280 | to move to this mixture of experts implementation.
00:30:14.280 | Historically, the reason why not everyone might do it
00:30:16.760 | is because it's an implementation complexity,
00:30:19.000 | especially when doing these big models.
00:30:21.080 | So this is one of the things that DeepSeq gets credit for
00:30:24.080 | is they do this extremely well.
00:30:26.040 | They do a mixture of experts extremely well.
00:30:27.720 | This architecture for what is called DeepSeq MOE,
00:30:31.360 | MOE is the shortened version of mixture of experts,
00:30:34.320 | is multiple papers old.
00:30:35.760 | This part of their training infrastructure
00:30:37.960 | is not new to these models alone.
00:30:40.840 | And same goes for what Dylan mentioned
00:30:42.960 | with multi-head latent attention.
00:30:45.280 | This is all about reducing memory usage during inference
00:30:48.200 | and same things during training
00:30:50.120 | by using some fancy low rank approximation math.
00:30:53.600 | If you get into the details with this latent attention,
00:30:56.680 | it's one of those things I look at and say,
00:30:58.320 | okay, they're doing really complex implementations
00:31:01.520 | 'cause there's other parts of language models
00:31:03.040 | such as embeddings that are used
00:31:05.800 | to extend the context length.
00:31:07.200 | The common one that DeepSeq uses
00:31:09.320 | rotary positional embeddings, which is called rope.
00:31:12.680 | And if you wanna use rope with a normal MOE,
00:31:15.280 | it's kind of a sequential thing.
00:31:16.440 | You take two of the attention matrices
00:31:19.320 | and you rotate them by a complex value rotation,
00:31:22.520 | which is a matrix multiplication.
00:31:24.360 | With DeepSeq's MLA, with this new attention architecture,
00:31:27.760 | they need to do some clever things
00:31:29.760 | because they're not set up the same
00:31:31.120 | and it just makes the implementation complexity much higher.
00:31:34.240 | So they're managing all of these things.
00:31:35.760 | And these are probably the sort of things
00:31:37.640 | that OpenAI, these closed labs are doing.
00:31:40.320 | We don't know if they're doing the exact same techniques,
00:31:42.200 | but they actually shared them with the world,
00:31:44.000 | which is really nice to feel like
00:31:45.240 | this is the cutting edge
00:31:46.520 | of efficient language model training.
00:31:49.160 | - And some of this requires low level engineering.
00:31:52.280 | Just it is a giant mess and trickery.
00:31:55.320 | So as I understand that one below CUDA,
00:31:57.800 | so they go super low programming of GPUs.
00:32:00.880 | - Effectively, NVIDIA builds this library called Nickel,
00:32:03.960 | right?
00:32:05.000 | In which, you know, when you're training a model,
00:32:07.200 | you have all these communications
00:32:08.760 | between every single layer of the model
00:32:10.880 | and you may have over a hundred layers.
00:32:12.440 | - What does Nickel stand for?
00:32:13.480 | It's N-C-C-L?
00:32:14.600 | - NVIDIA Communications Collectives Library.
00:32:16.720 | - Nice.
00:32:17.560 | (laughs)
00:32:18.400 | - And so,
00:32:19.240 | - Damn.
00:32:20.080 | (laughs)
00:32:20.920 | - When you're training a model, right?
00:32:22.960 | You're going to have all these,
00:32:24.160 | all reduces and all gathers, right?
00:32:26.080 | Between each layer,
00:32:27.000 | between the multi-layer perceptron or feed forward network
00:32:30.520 | and the attention mechanism,
00:32:31.720 | you'll have basically the model synchronized, right?
00:32:35.040 | Or you'll have all reduce or an all gather.
00:32:38.400 | And this is a communication
00:32:39.880 | between all the GPUs in the network,
00:32:41.240 | whether it's in training or inference.
00:32:43.080 | So NVIDIA has a standard library.
00:32:44.680 | This is one of the reasons why it's really difficult
00:32:47.240 | to use anyone else's hardware for training
00:32:49.600 | is because no one's really built
00:32:51.400 | a standard communications library.
00:32:53.520 | And NVIDIA has done this at a sort of a higher level, right?
00:32:56.240 | A DeepSeek,
00:32:57.080 | because they have certain limitations
00:32:58.720 | around the GPUs that they have access to,
00:33:00.680 | the interconnects are limited to some extent
00:33:03.880 | by the restrictions of the GPUs
00:33:05.800 | that were shipped into China legally,
00:33:07.080 | not the ones that are smuggled,
00:33:08.040 | but legally shipped in,
00:33:09.680 | that they use to train this model.
00:33:11.360 | They had to figure out how to get efficiencies, right?
00:33:15.200 | And one of those things is that
00:33:16.720 | instead of just calling the NVIDIA library, Nickel, right?
00:33:20.520 | They instead created their,
00:33:22.120 | they scheduled their own communications,
00:33:24.520 | which some of the labs do, right?
00:33:26.960 | Emeta talked about in Llama 3,
00:33:29.080 | how they made their own custom version of Nickel.
00:33:31.120 | This is, they didn't talk about the implementation details.
00:33:33.720 | This is some of what they did,
00:33:34.960 | probably not as well as,
00:33:36.360 | maybe not as well as DeepSeek
00:33:37.720 | because DeepSeek, you know,
00:33:38.840 | necessity is the mother of innovation.
00:33:40.680 | And they had to do this,
00:33:42.520 | whereas in the case, you know,
00:33:44.480 | OpenAI has people that do this sort of stuff,
00:33:46.600 | Anthropic, et cetera.
00:33:48.040 | But, you know, DeepSeek certainly did it publicly
00:33:50.400 | and they may have done it even better
00:33:51.560 | because they were gimped on a certain aspect
00:33:54.000 | of the chips that they have access to.
00:33:56.040 | And so they scheduled communications on,
00:34:00.600 | you know, by scheduling specific SMs.
00:34:02.520 | SMs you could think of as like the core on a GPU, right?
00:34:06.200 | So there's hundreds of cores,
00:34:08.080 | or there's, you know, a bit over a hundred cores, SMs,
00:34:10.760 | on a GPU and they were specifically scheduling,
00:34:13.120 | hey, which ones are running the model?
00:34:14.480 | Which ones are doing all reduce?
00:34:15.800 | Which one are doing all gather, right?
00:34:17.360 | And they would flip back and forth between them.
00:34:19.040 | And this requires extremely low level programming.
00:34:22.080 | - This is what Nickel does automatically
00:34:23.600 | or other NVIDIA libraries handle this automatically usually.
00:34:26.480 | - Yeah, exactly.
00:34:27.320 | And so technically they're using, you know, PTX,
00:34:29.960 | which is like sort of like,
00:34:31.360 | you could think of it as like an assembly type language.
00:34:33.840 | It's not exactly that or instruction set, right?
00:34:35.800 | Like coding directly to assembly or instruction set.
00:34:38.320 | It's not exactly that,
00:34:39.320 | but that's still part of technically CUDA,
00:34:42.000 | but it's like, do I wanna write in Python,
00:34:44.120 | you know, PyTorch equivalent and call NVIDIA libraries?
00:34:47.000 | Do I wanna go down to the C level, right?
00:34:49.000 | Or, you know, encode even lower level,
00:34:50.640 | or do I wanna go all the way down
00:34:51.560 | to the assembly or ISO level?
00:34:53.120 | And there are cases where you go all the way down there
00:34:55.880 | at the very big labs,
00:34:57.080 | but most companies just do not do that, right?
00:34:59.600 | Because it's a waste of time
00:35:01.000 | and the efficiency gains you get are not worth it.
00:35:03.640 | But DeepSeek's implementation is so complex, right?
00:35:06.840 | Especially with their mixture of experts, right?
00:35:09.360 | People have done mixture of experts,
00:35:10.680 | but they're generally eight, 16 experts, right?
00:35:13.360 | And they activate too.
00:35:14.240 | So, you know, one of the words that we like to use
00:35:17.000 | is like sparsity factor, right?
00:35:18.640 | Or usage, right?
00:35:19.480 | So you might have four, you know,
00:35:21.440 | one fourth of your model activate, right?
00:35:23.760 | And that's what Mistral's Mistral model, right?
00:35:27.560 | Their model that really catapulted them to like,
00:35:29.840 | oh my God, they're really, really good.
00:35:32.160 | OpenAI has also had models that are MOE
00:35:34.320 | and so have all the other labs that are major closed.
00:35:37.760 | But what DeepSeek did that maybe only the leading labs
00:35:40.720 | have only just started recently doing
00:35:42.480 | is have such a high sparsity factor, right?
00:35:44.200 | It's not one fourth of the model, right?
00:35:46.000 | Two out of eight experts activating
00:35:47.920 | every time you go through the model, it's eight out of 256.
00:35:51.400 | - And there's different implementations
00:35:52.960 | for mixture of experts where you can have
00:35:55.560 | some of these experts that are always activated,
00:35:58.680 | which this just looks like a small neural network
00:36:02.080 | and then all the tokens go through that.
00:36:03.720 | And then they also go through some that are selected
00:36:07.160 | by this routing mechanism.
00:36:08.720 | And one of the innovations in DeepSeek's architecture
00:36:12.960 | is that they changed the routing mechanism
00:36:15.080 | in mixture of expert models.
00:36:16.520 | There's something called an auxiliary loss,
00:36:19.160 | which effectively means during training,
00:36:21.440 | you want to make sure that all of these experts are used
00:36:23.960 | across the tasks that the model sees.
00:36:26.600 | Why there can be failures in mixture of experts
00:36:28.880 | is that when you're doing this training,
00:36:32.240 | the one objective is token prediction accuracy.
00:36:35.520 | And if you just let training go
00:36:37.240 | with a mixture of expert model on your own,
00:36:39.360 | it can be that the model learns
00:36:42.000 | to only use a subset of the experts.
00:36:44.720 | And in the MOE literature,
00:36:46.640 | there's something called the auxiliary loss,
00:36:48.560 | which helps balance them.
00:36:50.280 | But if you think about the loss functions of deep learning,
00:36:54.240 | this even connects to the bitter lesson
00:36:55.800 | is that you want to have the minimum inductive bias
00:36:59.480 | in your model to let the model learn maximally.
00:37:01.960 | And this auxiliary loss, this balancing across experts
00:37:05.040 | could be seen as intention
00:37:07.040 | with the prediction accuracy of the tokens.
00:37:09.600 | So we don't know the exact extent
00:37:11.120 | that the DeepSeek MOE change,
00:37:13.120 | which is instead of doing an auxiliary loss,
00:37:15.440 | they have an extra parameter in their routing,
00:37:17.760 | which after the batches, they update this parameter
00:37:20.760 | to make sure that the next batches
00:37:22.360 | all have a similar use of experts.
00:37:24.440 | And this type of change can be big, it can be small,
00:37:26.960 | but they add up over time.
00:37:28.720 | And this is the sort of thing
00:37:29.560 | that just points to them innovating.
00:37:31.160 | And I'm sure all the labs that are training big MOEs
00:37:33.800 | are looking at this sort of things,
00:37:35.080 | which is getting away from the auxiliary loss.
00:37:37.160 | Some of them might already use it,
00:37:38.680 | but you keep accumulating gains.
00:37:40.480 | And we'll talk about the philosophy of training
00:37:43.160 | and how you organize these organizations.
00:37:45.680 | And a lot of it is just compounding small improvements
00:37:48.280 | over time in your data, in your architecture,
00:37:50.520 | in your post-training
00:37:51.360 | and how they integrate with each other.
00:37:53.960 | DeepSeq does the same thing.
00:37:55.160 | And some of them are shared a lot.
00:37:57.440 | We have to take them on face value
00:37:58.680 | that they share their most important details.
00:38:00.760 | I mean, the architecture and the weights are out there.
00:38:02.280 | So we're seeing what they're doing.
00:38:04.000 | And it adds up.
00:38:05.200 | - Going back to sort of the like efficiency
00:38:07.200 | and complexity point, right?
00:38:08.320 | It's 32 versus four, right?
00:38:11.240 | For like Mixedraw and other MOE models
00:38:12.920 | that have been publicly released.
00:38:14.400 | So this ratio is extremely high.
00:38:16.040 | And sort of what Nathan was getting at there was
00:38:18.640 | when you have such a different level of sparsity,
00:38:21.920 | you can't just have every GPU have the entire model, right?
00:38:25.440 | The model's too big.
00:38:26.320 | There's too much complexity there.
00:38:27.720 | So you have to split up the model
00:38:29.480 | with different types of parallelism, right?
00:38:31.320 | And so you might have different experts
00:38:32.880 | on different GPU nodes.
00:38:34.480 | But now what happens when this set of data that you get,
00:38:38.440 | hey, all of it looks like this one way
00:38:40.240 | and all of it should route to one part of my model, right?
00:38:43.240 | So when all of it routes to one part of the model,
00:38:47.320 | then you can have this overloading
00:38:51.120 | of a certain set of the GPU resources
00:38:53.600 | or a certain set of the GPUs.
00:38:55.160 | And then the rest of the training network sits idle
00:38:58.760 | because all of the tokens are just routing to that.
00:39:00.520 | So this is the biggest complexity.
00:39:01.720 | One of the big complexities
00:39:02.600 | with running a very sparse mixture of experts model,
00:39:06.960 | i.e. this 32 ratio versus this four ratio
00:39:10.840 | is that you end up with so many of the experts
00:39:13.120 | just sitting there idle.
00:39:14.200 | So how do I load balance between them?

00:47:38.520 | And it's just continuing to build the capabilities
00:47:41.360 | that they have.
00:47:42.360 | - There's the concept of a YOLO run.
00:47:44.200 | So YOLO, you only live once.
00:47:47.360 | And what it is, is like there's all this experimentation
00:47:50.840 | you do at the small scale, right?

00:48:08.920 | you're testing at a very small scale, right?

00:48:12.960 | tens of GPUs, hundreds of GPUs, whatever it is.

00:48:16.520 | okay guys, no more fucking around, right?

00:48:19.840 | Everyone take all the resources we have,
00:48:23.000 | let's pick what we think will work
00:48:24.600 | and just go for it, right?
00:48:25.600 | YOLO.
00:48:26.440 | And this is where that sort of stress comes in is like,
00:48:29.000 | well, I know it works here,
00:48:30.320 | but some things that work here don't work here.
00:48:32.520 | And some things that work here don't work down here, right?
00:48:35.000 | In this terms of scale, right?
00:48:36.320 | So it's really truly a YOLO run.
00:48:39.520 | And sort of like, there's this like discussion
00:48:42.760 | of like certain researchers
00:48:43.760 | just have like this methodical nature,
00:48:45.360 | like they can find the whole search space

00:48:49.840 | and really see what is best.
00:48:51.400 | And there's certain researchers who just kind of like,
00:48:53.760 | you know, have that innate gut instinct of like,
00:48:56.160 | this is the YOLO run.
00:48:57.240 | Like, you know, looking at the data, this is it.
00:49:00.160 | - This is why you want to work in post-training
00:49:01.680 | because the GPU costs for training is lower.
00:49:03.720 | So you can make a higher percentage of your training runs
00:49:05.720 | YOLO runs.
00:49:06.800 | - Yeah.
00:49:07.640 | - For now.
00:49:08.480 | - Yeah, for now, for now.
00:49:10.440 | So some of this is fundamentally luck still.

00:49:15.800 | In many cases.

00:49:20.240 | if you're on one of these labs,

01:32:35.740 | doubling the cost of fabs every handful of years.
01:32:38.060 | And so you look at a leading edge fab

01:34:24.700 | - Economies of scale.
01:34:26.080 | - Scale.
01:34:26.920 | - Yeah, so I mean, like I mentioned, right?

01:34:56.620 | you have to make real architectural innovations, right?

01:35:24.960 | And it's a cool door handle, right?
01:35:26.400 | It's like, you know, you don't think about it,
01:35:27.480 | but it's like has two really chipped,
01:35:28.960 | like penny, like chips in there, right?
01:35:31.560 | Anyway, so as you have more diversity of chips,
01:35:34.480 | as you have more specialization required,
01:35:36.400 | and the cost of fabs continues to grow,
01:35:38.340 | you need someone who is laser focused
01:35:40.580 | on building the best process technology
01:35:43.300 | and making it as flexible as possible.
01:35:45.840 | - I think you could say it simply,
01:35:46.900 | which is the cost per fab goes up.
01:35:49.620 | And if you are a small player
01:35:51.400 | that makes a few types of chips,
01:35:53.180 | you're not gonna have the demand
01:35:54.760 | to pay back the cost of the fab.
01:35:56.580 | Whereas NVIDIA can have many different customers
01:35:59.020 | and aggregate all this demand into one place.
01:36:01.860 | And then they're the only person
01:36:03.160 | that makes enough money building chips
01:36:05.780 | to buy the next, to build the next fab.
01:36:08.700 | So this is kind of why the companies slowly get killed
01:36:11.180 | 'cause they have 10 years ago,
01:36:14.220 | a chip that is profitable and is good enough,
01:36:16.540 | but the cost to build the next one goes up.
01:36:18.460 | They may try to do this,
01:36:20.140 | fail because they don't have the money to make it work,
01:36:22.100 | and then they don't have any chips,
01:36:23.180 | or they build it and it's too expensive
01:36:24.780 | and they just have not profitable chips.
01:36:26.780 | - You know, there's more failure points, right?
01:36:28.500 | You know, you could have one little process
01:36:30.380 | related to like some sort of like a chemical etch
01:36:33.500 | or some sort of like plasma etch,
01:36:35.060 | or some little process that screws up,
01:36:37.500 | you didn't engineer it right,
01:36:38.860 | and now the whole company falls apart,
01:36:40.300 | you can't make chips, right?
01:36:41.300 | And so super, super powerful companies like Intel,
01:36:44.380 | they had like the weathering storm to like,
01:36:46.260 | hey, they still exist today,
01:36:47.340 | even though they really screwed up their manufacturing
01:36:49.740 | six, seven years ago.
01:36:50.740 | But in the case of like AMD, they almost went bankrupt.
01:36:53.300 | They had to sell their fabs to Mubadala, UAE, right?
01:36:57.580 | And like that became a separate company
01:36:59.220 | called Global Foundries, which is a foundry firm.
01:37:01.980 | And then AMD was able to then focus
01:37:03.660 | on like on the return back up was like,
01:37:05.340 | hey, let's focus on making chiplets
01:37:07.300 | and a bunch of different chips for different markets
01:37:10.060 | and focusing on specific workloads
01:37:11.980 | rather than, you know, all of these different things.
01:37:14.580 | And so you get more diversity of chips,
01:37:16.060 | you have more companies than ever designing chips,
01:37:18.540 | but you have fewer companies
01:37:19.500 | than ever manufacturing them, right?
01:37:21.540 | And this is where TSMC comes in
01:37:23.860 | as they've just been the best, right?
01:37:25.980 | They are so good at it, right?
01:37:27.820 | They're customer focused,
01:37:28.900 | they make it easy for you to fabricate your chips,
01:37:31.020 | they take all of that complexity
01:37:32.340 | and like kind of try and abstract a lot of it away from you.
01:37:35.260 | They make good money, they don't make insane money,
01:37:37.180 | but they make good money.
01:37:39.100 | And they're able to aggregate all this demand
01:37:41.700 | and continue to build the next fab,
01:37:43.100 | the next fab, the next fab.
01:37:44.060 | - So why is Taiwan so special for TSMC?

01:52:52.300 | had a lock hold over not just themselves,

01:52:56.020 | And likewise, the most peaceful time in human history
01:52:59.620 | has been when the US was the global hegemon, right?

01:55:55.300 | And, you know, you could think of chips
01:55:56.940 | along three axes for AI, right?
01:55:59.500 | You know, ignoring software stack and like exact architecture
01:56:02.780 | just raw specifications.
01:56:04.260 | There's floating point operations, right?

01:56:11.860 | And then there is interconnect, right?

01:56:18.380 | for making AI systems, right?
01:56:21.380 | 'Cause AI systems involve a lot of compute.
01:56:23.300 | They involve a lot of moving memory around,
01:56:25.500 | whether it be to memory or to other chips, right?
01:56:27.940 | And so these three vectors,
01:56:30.180 | the US initially had a multi, you know,
01:56:32.180 | had two of these vectors controlled
01:56:33.580 | and one of them not controlled,
01:56:34.580 | which was flops and interconnect bandwidth
01:56:36.540 | were initially controlled.
01:56:37.700 | And then they said, no, no, no, no,

01:56:40.340 | and just make it a very simple only flops.
01:56:42.700 | But now Nvidia can now make a chip that has,
01:56:45.420 | okay, it's cut down on flops.
01:56:47.140 | It's, you know, it's like one third that of the H100, right?

01:56:54.900 | You know, in real world, it's closer to like half
01:56:56.900 | or maybe even like 60% of it, right?
01:56:59.540 | But then on the other two vectors,

01:59:17.340 | - Memory, right?

01:59:20.680 | - I would say there's two articles in this one
01:59:23.380 | that I could show,

01:59:26.820 | - For the listeners,
01:59:27.660 | we're looking at the section

01:59:32.380 | - Hmm, you wanna explain KVCache before we talk about this?
01:59:35.060 | I think like it's better to--
01:59:36.060 | - Okay, yeah, we need to go through
01:59:37.900 | a lot of specific technical things of transformers
01:59:41.060 | to make this easier for people.
01:59:42.780 | - Because it's incredibly important
01:59:44.780 | because this changes how models work.
01:59:46.220 | But I think resetting, right?
01:59:48.340 | Why is memory so important?
01:59:51.180 | It's because so far we've talked about parameter counts,
01:59:53.420 | right?
01:59:54.260 | And mixture of experts,
01:59:55.080 | you can change how many active parameters
01:59:56.620 | versus total parameters to embed more data,
01:59:58.420 | but have less flops.
01:59:59.700 | But more important, you know,
02:00:01.540 | another aspect of, you know,
02:00:03.020 | what's part of this humongous revolution
02:00:04.700 | in the last handful of years,
02:00:05.900 | is the transformer, right?
02:00:07.180 | And the attention mechanism.
02:00:08.340 | Attention mechanism is that the model
02:00:10.500 | understands the relationships
02:00:12.340 | between all the words in its context, right?
02:00:14.580 | And that is separate from the parameters themselves, right?
02:00:18.780 | And that is something that you must calculate, right?
02:00:21.900 | How each token, right?
02:00:23.460 | Each word in the context length
02:00:25.260 | is relatively connected to each other, right?
02:00:29.020 | And I think, Nathan,
02:00:30.220 | you should explain KVCache better.
02:00:31.780 | - KVCache is one of the optimizations.
02:00:33.140 | - Yeah, so the attention operator has three core things.
02:00:37.100 | It's queries, keys, and values.
02:00:39.540 | QKV is the thing that goes into this.
02:00:42.660 | You'll look at the equation.
02:00:44.040 | You see that these matrices are multiplied together.
02:00:46.620 | These words, query, key, and value
02:00:48.380 | come from information retrieval backgrounds
02:00:50.380 | where the query is the thing
02:00:52.540 | you're trying to get the values for.
02:00:53.780 | And you access the keys and the values is reweighting.
02:00:56.540 | My background's not in information retrieval
02:00:58.780 | and things like this.
02:00:59.620 | I just want to have backlinks.
02:01:01.380 | And what effectively happens
02:01:03.540 | is that when you're doing these matrix multiplications,
02:01:06.180 | you're having matrices that are of the size
02:01:08.900 | of the context length.
02:01:09.780 | So the number of tokens that you put into the model.
02:01:11.900 | And the KVCache is effectively
02:01:14.860 | some form of compressed representation
02:01:17.100 | of all the previous tokens in the model.
02:01:19.380 | So when you're doing this,
02:01:20.600 | we talk about autoregressive models,
02:01:22.580 | you predict one token at a time.
02:01:24.320 | You start with whatever your prompt was.
02:01:26.300 | You ask a question like who was the president in 1825?
02:01:30.100 | The model then is going to generate its first token.
02:01:32.420 | For each of these tokens,
02:01:34.060 | you're doing the same attention operator
02:01:36.220 | where you're multiplying these query key value matrices.
02:01:40.140 | But the math is very nice
02:01:42.460 | so that when you're doing this repeatedly,
02:01:44.740 | this KVCache, this key value operation,
02:01:48.940 | you can keep appending the new values to it.
02:01:51.320 | So you keep track of what your previous values
02:01:53.740 | you're inferring over in this autoregressive chain,
02:01:56.540 | you keep it in memory the whole time.
02:01:58.660 | And this is a really crucial thing to manage
02:02:02.040 | when serving inference at scale.
02:02:04.300 | There are far bigger experts in this
02:02:06.140 | and there are so many levels of detail
02:02:08.020 | that you can go into.
02:02:09.420 | Essentially, one of the key "drawbacks"
02:02:13.380 | of the attention operator and the transformer
02:02:16.180 | is that there is a form of quadratic memory cost
02:02:18.860 | in proportion to the context length.
02:02:21.540 | So as you put in longer questions,
02:02:23.780 | the memory used in order to make that computation
02:02:27.180 | is going up in the form of a quadratic.
02:02:29.540 | You'll hear about a lot of other language model architectures
02:02:33.180 | that are like subquadratic or linear attention forms,
02:02:36.660 | which is like state-space models.
02:02:38.540 | We don't need to go down all these now.
02:02:40.100 | And then there's innovations on attention
02:02:42.500 | to make this memory usage
02:02:44.740 | and the ability to attend over long contexts
02:02:48.180 | much more accurate and high performance.
02:02:50.260 | - And those innovations are going to help you with,
02:02:52.420 | I mean, you're highly memory constrained.
02:02:53.980 | - They help with memory constraint and performance.
02:02:55.940 | So if you put in a book into, I think,
02:02:58.340 | Gemini is the model that has the longest context length
02:03:00.540 | that people are using.
02:03:01.380 | Gemini is known for 1 million
02:03:02.540 | and now 2 million context length.
02:03:04.300 | You put a whole book into Gemini
02:03:06.380 | and sometimes it'll draw facts out of it.
02:03:09.300 | It's not perfect, they're getting better,
02:03:11.220 | but the, so there's two things.
02:03:12.940 | It's like one, to be able to serve this
02:03:14.700 | on the memory level.
02:03:15.540 | Google has magic with their TPU stack
02:03:17.660 | where they can serve really long contexts.
02:03:19.540 | And then there's also many decisions along the way
02:03:21.940 | to actually make long context performance work.
02:03:24.100 | This implies the data,
02:03:25.500 | there's subtle changes to these computations in attention,
02:03:28.820 | and it just, it changes the architecture.
02:03:31.140 | But serving long contexts is extremely memory constrained,
02:03:35.300 | especially when you're making a lot of predictions.
02:03:37.020 | I actually don't know why input and output tokens
02:03:40.620 | are more expensive,
02:03:41.460 | but I think essentially output tokens,
02:03:42.900 | you have to do more computation
02:03:44.380 | 'cause you have to sample from the model.
02:03:45.860 | - I can explain that.
02:03:46.700 | So today, if you use a model,
02:03:48.980 | like you look at an API,
02:03:50.220 | OpenAI charges a certain price per million tokens.
02:03:54.900 | And that price for input and output tokens is different.
02:03:58.020 | And the reason is that there is,
02:04:01.260 | when you're inputting a query into the model,
02:04:04.020 | let's say you have a book,
02:04:06.020 | that book you must now calculate the entire KV cache for,
02:04:09.140 | this key value cache.
02:04:10.260 | And so when you do that, that is a parallel operation.
02:04:13.500 | All of the tokens can be processed at one time.
02:04:15.900 | And therefore you can dramatically reduce
02:04:18.100 | how much you're spending, right?
02:04:19.300 | The flop requirements for generating a token
02:04:21.740 | and an input token are identical, right?
02:04:24.300 | If I input one token or if I generate one token,
02:04:26.540 | it's completely identical.
02:04:27.540 | I have to go through the model, right?
02:04:28.740 | But the difference is that I can do that input,
02:04:31.660 | i.e. the pre-fill, i.e. the prompt,
02:04:34.100 | simultaneously in a batch nature, right?
02:04:37.340 | And therefore it is all flop.
02:04:38.860 | - I think the pricing model,
02:04:39.940 | mostly they use this for input tokens
02:04:42.460 | is about one fourth the price of the output tokens.
02:04:44.260 | - Correct.
02:04:45.100 | But then output tokens,
02:04:46.100 | the reason why it's so expensive
02:04:47.340 | is because I can't do it in parallel, right?
02:04:48.740 | It's autoregressive.
02:04:49.820 | Every time I generate a token,
02:04:51.300 | I must not only take the entire,
02:04:53.620 | I must not only read the whole entire model into memory,
02:04:56.180 | right?
02:04:57.020 | And activate it, right?
02:04:57.900 | Go calculate it to generate the next token.
02:04:59.780 | I also have to read the entire KV cache.
02:05:01.700 | And I generate a token and I append that KV,
02:05:03.980 | that one token I generated and it's KV cache.
02:05:06.420 | And then I do it again, right?
02:05:07.620 | And so therefore this is a non-parallel operation.
02:05:10.820 | And this is one where you have to,
02:05:13.660 | in the case of pre-fill or prompt,
02:05:15.580 | you pull the whole model in
02:05:17.220 | and you calculate 20,000 tokens at once, right?
02:05:19.900 | - So these are features that APIs are shipping,
02:05:22.060 | which is like prompt caching, pre-filling,
02:05:25.740 | 'cause you can drive prices down
02:05:27.060 | and you can make APIs much faster.
02:05:28.460 | If you know you're gonna keep,
02:05:29.740 | if you run a business
02:05:30.580 | and you're gonna keep passing the same initial content
02:05:33.100 | to Cloud's API,
02:05:34.420 | you can load that in to the Anthropic API
02:05:37.180 | and always keep it there.
02:05:38.540 | But it's very different
02:05:39.380 | than we're kind of leading to the reasoning models,
02:05:41.620 | which we talked,
02:05:42.460 | we showed this example earlier
02:05:43.540 | and read some of this kind of mumbling stuff.
02:05:46.740 | And what happens is that
02:05:48.940 | the output context length is so much higher.
02:05:51.420 | And I mean, I learned a lot about this from Dylan's work,
02:05:53.500 | which is essentially as the output length gets higher,
02:05:56.140 | you're using this,
02:05:57.020 | you're writing this quadratic in terms of memory used.
02:05:59.700 | And then the GPUs that we have,
02:06:02.260 | effectively you're gonna run out of memory
02:06:04.860 | and they're all trying to serve multiple requests at once.
02:06:07.260 | So they're doing this batch processing
02:06:08.660 | where not all of the prompts are exactly the same,
02:06:10.540 | really complex handling.
02:06:11.940 | And then as context lengths gets longer,
02:06:14.260 | there's this like,
02:06:15.140 | I think you call it critical batch size,
02:06:17.060 | where your ability to serve more users.
02:06:20.660 | So how much you can parallelize your inference plummets
02:06:24.220 | because of this long context.
02:06:25.420 | So your memory usage is going way up
02:06:28.060 | with these reasoning models
02:06:29.180 | and you still have a lot of users.
02:06:30.700 | So effectively the cost to serve multiplies by a ton.
02:06:35.020 | - And we're looking at a plot
02:06:36.580 | when the X-axis is a sequence length.
02:06:39.900 | IE, how many tokens are being generated slash prompt.
02:06:43.380 | So if I put in a book, that's a million tokens.
02:06:45.740 | But if I put in, the sky is blue,
02:06:48.220 | then that's like six tokens or whatever.
02:06:49.060 | - And we should say that what we're calling reasoning
02:06:51.940 | and chain of thought is extending this sequence length.
02:06:55.500 | - It's mostly output.
02:06:56.700 | So before, three months ago, whenever O1 launched,
02:06:59.620 | all of the use cases for long context length
02:07:02.140 | were like, let me put a ton of documents in
02:07:04.020 | and then get an answer out.
02:07:05.500 | And it's a single pre-fill, compute a lot in parallel,
02:07:09.740 | and then output a little bit.
02:07:11.260 | Now with reasoning and agents,
02:07:13.420 | this is a very different idea.
02:07:15.100 | Now instead, I might only have like,
02:07:17.260 | hey, do this task or I might have all these documents.
02:07:19.260 | But at the end of the day,
02:07:20.500 | the model is not just like producing a little bit.
02:07:22.700 | It's producing tons of information.
02:07:24.820 | This chain of thought just continues to go
02:07:26.900 | and go and go and go.
02:07:28.300 | And so the sequence length is effectively that,
02:07:31.260 | if it's generated 10,000 tokens,
02:07:33.100 | it's 10,000 sequence length.
02:07:34.940 | And plus whatever you inputted in the prompt.
02:07:37.340 | And so what this chart is showing,
02:07:38.580 | and it's a logarithmic chart, right?
02:07:40.100 | Is, you know, as you go from 1K to 4K or 4K to 16K,
02:07:45.100 | the memory requirements grow so fast for your KV cache
02:07:50.500 | that you end up not being able to run a certain number of,
02:07:54.260 | you know, your sequence length is capped
02:07:56.700 | or the number of users you can serve.
02:07:57.660 | - Let's say the model.
02:07:58.500 | So this is showing for a 405B model in batch size 64.
02:08:02.340 | - Lama 3145D.
02:08:04.260 | - Yeah, and batch size is crucial too.
02:08:06.300 | Essentially you wanna have higher batch size
02:08:09.140 | to parallelize, parallel your throughput.
02:08:11.620 | - 64 different users at once, right?
02:08:13.060 | - Yeah.
02:08:13.900 | - And therefore your serving costs are lower, right?
02:08:15.060 | 'Cause the server costs the same, right?
02:08:16.580 | This is eight H100s, roughly $2 an hour per GPU.
02:08:19.900 | That's $16 an hour, right?
02:08:21.620 | That is like somewhat of a fixed cost.
02:08:23.860 | You can do things to make it lower, of course.
02:08:25.180 | But like, it's like $16 an hour.
02:08:26.820 | Now, how many users can you serve?
02:08:28.540 | How many tokens can you generate?
02:08:30.020 | And then you divide the two and that's your cost, right?
02:08:32.100 | And so with reasoning models,
02:08:34.500 | this is where a lot of the complexity comes about
02:08:37.220 | and why memory is so important.
02:08:38.780 | Because if you have limited amounts of memory,
02:08:41.180 | then you can't serve so many users.
02:08:43.020 | If you have limited amounts of memory,
02:08:44.540 | your serving speeds get lower, right?
02:08:46.300 | And so your costs get a lot, lot worse.
02:08:49.180 | Because all of a sudden, if I was used to,
02:08:51.300 | hey, on this $16 an hour server,
02:08:52.980 | I'm serving Lama 405B, or if I'm serving, you know,
02:08:56.100 | DeepSeek V3, and it's all chat style applications,
02:08:59.500 | i.e. we're just chit-chatting.
02:09:00.940 | The sequence lengths are a thousand, a few thousand, right?
02:09:04.220 | You know, when you use a language model,
02:09:05.340 | it's a few thousand context lengths most of the time.
02:09:06.740 | Sometimes you're dropping a big document,
02:09:08.220 | but then you process it, you get your answer,
02:09:10.260 | you throw it away, right?
02:09:11.100 | You move on to the next thing, right?
02:09:12.620 | Whereas with reasoning,
02:09:14.260 | I'm now generating tens of thousands of tokens in sequence,
02:09:17.620 | right?
02:09:18.460 | And so this memory, this KVCache has to stay resident
02:09:21.420 | and you have to keep loading it.
02:09:22.420 | You have to keep it in memory constantly.
02:09:24.780 | And now this butts out other users, right?
02:09:27.060 | If there's now a reasoning task, right?
02:09:29.140 | And the model's capable of reasoning,
02:09:30.780 | then all of a sudden that memory pressure
02:09:34.180 | means that I can't serve as many users simultaneously.
02:09:36.260 | - Let's go into DeepSeek again.

02:39:25.900 | have very fine-grained control

02:39:28.660 | through techniques like RLHF.

02:39:33.180 | Like on one end of the spectrum is Google.
02:39:36.260 | And then like maybe OpenAI does less
02:39:38.140 | and Anthropic does less.

02:39:42.900 | but they all have different forms of RLHF
02:39:45.500 | trying to make them a certain way.
02:39:47.260 | - And like the important thing to say
02:39:49.780 | is that no matter how you want the model to behave,
02:39:53.600 | these RLHF and preference tuning techniques
02:39:55.660 | also improve performance.
02:39:57.020 | So on things like math evals and code evals,
02:39:59.580 | there is something innate to these,
02:40:01.500 | what is called contrastive loss functions.
02:40:03.840 | We could start to get into RL here.
02:40:05.420 | We don't really need to,
02:40:06.260 | but RLHF also boosts performance on anything
02:40:08.860 | from a chat task to a math problem to a code problem.
02:40:11.980 | So it is becoming a much more useful tool to these labs.
02:40:16.060 | So this kind of takes us through the arc
02:40:17.780 | of we've talked about pre-training,
02:40:19.020 | hard to get rid of things.
02:40:20.260 | We've talked about post-training
02:40:21.380 | and how post-training, you can mess it up.
02:40:23.900 | It's a complex multifaceted optimization
02:40:26.660 | with 10 to 100 person teams converging on one artifact.
02:40:30.260 | It's really easy to not do it perfectly.
02:40:32.580 | And then there's the third case,
02:40:33.660 | which is what we talked about Gemini.
02:40:35.420 | The thing that was about Gemini
02:40:36.940 | is this was a served product
02:40:38.980 | where Google has their internal model weights.
02:40:40.980 | They've done all these processes that we talked about.
02:40:43.020 | And in the served product,
02:40:44.340 | what came out after this was that they had a prompt
02:40:46.720 | that they were rewriting user queries
02:40:48.440 | to boost diversity or something.
02:40:50.860 | And this just made it,
02:40:52.240 | the outputs were just blatantly wrong.
02:40:53.860 | It was some sort of organizational failure
02:40:56.380 | that had this prompt in that position.
02:40:58.440 | And I think Google executives probably have owned this.
02:41:01.260 | I didn't pay that attention to that detail,
02:41:03.040 | but it was just a mess up in execution
02:41:05.360 | that led to this ridiculous thing.
02:41:06.860 | But at the system level,
02:41:07.980 | the model weights might have been fine.
02:41:09.760 | - So at the very end of the pipeline,
02:41:11.700 | there was a rewriting.
02:41:12.820 | - To something like a system prompt.
02:41:14.420 | It was like the system prompt
02:41:16.260 | or what is called an industry is like you rewrite prompts.
02:41:19.820 | So especially for image models,
02:41:21.860 | if you're using DALI or chat GPT can generate you an image,
02:41:25.900 | you'll say, draw me a beautiful car.
02:41:27.900 | With these leading image models,
02:41:30.660 | they benefit from highly descriptive prompts.
02:41:33.780 | So what would happen is if you do that on chat GPT,
02:41:36.640 | a language model behind the scenes will rewrite the prompt,
02:41:39.180 | say, make this more descriptive.
02:41:41.100 | And then that is passed to the image model.
02:41:42.860 | So prompt rewriting is something that is used
02:41:44.700 | at multiple levels of industry
02:41:46.620 | and it's used effectively for image models.
02:41:48.420 | And the Gemini example is just a failed execution.
02:41:52.460 | - Big philosophical question here with RLHF to generalize,
02:41:57.460 | where is human input, human in the loop,
02:42:02.340 | human data most useful at the current stage?
02:42:06.500 | - For the past few years,
02:42:08.240 | the highest cost human data has been in these preferences,
02:42:12.340 | which is comparing, I would say highest cost
02:42:15.160 | and highest total usage.
02:42:16.960 | So a lot of money has gone to these pairwise comparisons
02:42:20.040 | where you have two model outputs
02:42:21.300 | and a human is comparing between the two of them.
02:42:24.540 | In earlier years,
02:42:25.680 | there was a lot of this instruction tuning data.
02:42:27.940 | So creating highly specific examples
02:42:31.320 | to something like a Reddit question
02:42:32.820 | to a domain that you care about.
02:42:34.620 | Language models used to struggle on math and code.
02:42:36.760 | So you would pay experts in math and code
02:42:38.580 | to come up with questions and write detailed answers
02:42:41.100 | that were used to train the models.
02:42:42.940 | Now it is the case that there are many model options
02:42:47.180 | that are way better than humans at writing detailed
02:42:49.740 | and eloquent answers for things like model and code.
02:42:52.900 | So they talked about this with the LLAMA3 release
02:42:55.680 | where they switched to using LLAMA3 405B
02:42:58.920 | to write their answers for math and code.
02:43:01.380 | But they, in their paper,
02:43:03.220 | talk about how they use extensive human preference data,
02:43:06.400 | which is something that they haven't gotten AIs to replace.
02:43:08.800 | There are other techniques in industry
02:43:10.220 | like constitutional AI,
02:43:11.260 | where you use human data for preferences
02:43:13.100 | and AI for preferences.
02:43:14.380 | And I expect the AI part to scale faster
02:43:17.180 | than the human part.
02:43:18.500 | But among the research that we have access to
02:43:20.980 | is that humans are in this kind of preference loop.
02:43:24.920 | - So as reasoning becomes bigger and bigger and bigger,
02:43:28.060 | as we said, where's the role of humans in that?
02:43:30.980 | - It's even less prevalent.
02:43:33.060 | So it's the remarkable thing about these reasoning results,
02:43:36.740 | and especially the DeepSeq R1 paper is this result
02:43:39.660 | that they call DeepSeq R1-0,
02:43:41.620 | which is they took one of these pre-trained models,
02:43:43.500 | they took DeepSeq V3 base,

02:43:48.540 | on verifiable questions or verifiable rewards
02:43:51.500 | for a lot of questions and a lot of training.
02:43:54.180 | And these reasoning behaviors emerge nastrally.
02:43:56.580 | So these things like, wait, let me see,
02:43:58.340 | wait, let me check this.
02:43:59.940 | Oh, that might be a mistake.
02:44:01.440 | And they emerge from only having questions and answers.
02:44:05.340 | And when you're using the model,
02:44:06.540 | the part that you look at is the completion.
02:44:08.620 | So in this case, all of that just emerges
02:44:11.380 | from this large-scale RL training.
02:44:13.140 | And that model, which the weights are available,
02:44:16.580 | has no human preferences added into the post-training.
02:44:20.420 | There are, the DeepSeq R1 full model
02:44:23.020 | has some of this human preference tuning,
02:44:25.000 | this RLHF, after the reasoning stage.
02:44:27.860 | But the very remarkable thing
02:44:29.140 | is that you can get these reasoning behaviors,
02:44:31.760 | and it's very unlikely
02:44:32.880 | that there's humans writing out reasoning chains.
02:44:34.960 | It's very unlikely that they somehow hacked OpenAI
02:44:37.500 | and they got access to OpenAI-01's reasoning chains.
02:44:40.940 | It's something about the pre-trained language models
02:44:43.880 | and this RL training where you reward the model
02:44:46.200 | for getting the question right.
02:44:47.960 | And therefore, it's trying multiple solutions,
02:44:49.920 | and it emerges this chain of thought.
02:44:52.840 | - This might be a good place to mention
02:44:55.640 | the eloquent and the insightful tweet
02:44:59.540 | of the great and the powerful Andrej Karpathy.
02:45:02.380 | I think he had a bunch of thoughts,
02:45:03.780 | but one of them, last thought,
02:45:05.540 | not sure if this is obvious.
02:45:07.300 | You know something profound is coming
02:45:08.660 | when you're saying it's not sure if it's obvious.
02:45:11.540 | There are two major types of learning
02:45:13.180 | in both children and in deep learning.
02:45:15.580 | There's one, imitation learning, watch and repeat,
02:45:18.820 | i.e. pre-training, supervised fine-tuning,
02:45:21.580 | and two, trial and error learning, reinforcement learning.
02:45:25.460 | My favorite simple example is AlphaGo.
02:45:27.800 | One is learning by imitating expert players.
02:45:30.960 | Two is reinforcement learning to win the game.
02:45:33.560 | Almost every single shocking result of deep learning
02:45:36.960 | and the source of all magic is always two.
02:45:40.760 | Two is significantly more powerful.
02:45:42.960 | Two is what surprises you.
02:45:44.800 | Two is when the paddle learns to hit the ball
02:45:47.580 | behind the blocks and break out.
02:45:49.160 | Two is when AlphaGo beats even Lee Sedol.
02:45:52.560 | And two is the aha moment when the deep seek
02:45:56.500 | or O1, et cetera, discovers that it works well
02:45:59.660 | to reevaluate your assumptions,
02:46:02.100 | backtrack, try something else, et cetera.
02:46:04.700 | It's the solving strategies you see this model use
02:46:08.540 | in its chain of thought.
02:46:09.940 | It's how it goes back and forth thinking to itself.
02:46:13.380 | These thoughts are emergent, three exclamation points.
02:46:17.300 | And this is actually seriously incredible,
02:46:19.820 | impressive, and new, and is publicly available
02:46:22.720 | and documented.
02:46:24.060 | The model could never learn this with imitation
02:46:28.220 | because the cognition of the model
02:46:30.300 | and the cognition of the human labeler is different.
02:46:33.100 | The human would never know to correctly annotate
02:46:35.280 | these kinds of solving strategies
02:46:37.300 | and what they should even look like.
02:46:39.880 | They have to be discovered during reinforcement learning
02:46:42.160 | as empirically and statistically useful
02:46:43.740 | towards the final outcome.
02:46:45.340 | Anyway, the alpha zero sort of metaphor analogy here.
02:46:49.480 | Can you speak to that, the magic of the chain of thought
02:46:52.780 | that he's referring to?
02:46:54.060 | - I think it's good to recap alpha go and alpha zero
02:46:56.580 | because it plays nicely with these analogies
02:46:58.580 | between imitation learning and learning from scratch.
02:47:00.420 | So alpha go, the beginning of the process
02:47:03.620 | was learning from humans where they started the first,
02:47:06.940 | this is the first expert level go player or chess player
02:47:10.440 | in DeepMind's series of models
02:47:11.700 | where they had some human data.

02:47:15.620 | is that there was zero human data in the loop.
02:47:18.140 | And that change to alpha zero made a model
02:47:20.680 | that was dramatically more powerful for DeepMind.
02:47:23.000 | So this remove of the human prior,
02:47:25.880 | the human inductive bias makes the final system
02:47:28.880 | far more powerful.

02:49:14.980 | Humans are way, way, way more sample efficient.
02:49:17.220 | That is because of the self-play, right?

02:49:21.580 | As it sticks its foot in its mouth and it says,
02:49:24.220 | "Oh, this is my body," right?

02:49:29.460 | on its fingers with the most sensitive touch thing
02:49:31.580 | on its tongue, right?
02:49:32.420 | It's how babies learn.
02:49:33.540 | And it's just self-play over and over and over and over again.
02:49:37.340 | And now we have something that is similar to that, right?

02:53:49.740 | - There's surprising evidence that once you set up
02:53:52.620 | the ways of collecting the verifiable domain
02:53:54.780 | that this can work.
02:53:56.220 | There's been a lot of research before this R1
02:53:59.360 | on math problems.
02:54:00.520 | And they approach math with language models
02:54:02.840 | just by increasing the number of samples.
02:54:04.840 | So you can just try again and again and again.
02:54:06.840 | And you look at the amount of times
02:54:09.200 | that the language models get it right.
02:54:10.960 | And what we see is that even very bad models
02:54:14.480 | get it right sometimes.
02:54:15.840 | And the whole idea behind reinforcement learning
02:54:18.100 | is that you can learn from very sparse rewards.
02:54:20.520 | So it doesn't, the space of language
02:54:23.920 | and the space of tokens,
02:54:24.800 | whether you're generating language or tasks for a robot
02:54:27.160 | is so big that you might say that it's like,
02:54:30.080 | I mean, the tokenizer for a language model
02:54:32.200 | can be like 200,000 things.
02:54:33.400 | So at each step, it can sample from that big of a space.
02:54:36.280 | So if it can generate a bit of a signal
02:54:38.940 | that it can climb onto,
02:54:39.960 | that's what the whole field of RL is around
02:54:42.840 | is learning from sparse rewards.
02:54:45.160 | And the same thing has played out in math
02:54:47.040 | where it's like very weak models
02:54:48.480 | that sometimes generate answers.
02:54:49.960 | We see research already that you can boost
02:54:52.520 | their math scores.
02:54:53.360 | You can do this sort of RL training for math.
02:54:56.480 | It might not be as effective,
02:54:57.840 | but if you take a 1 billion parameter model,
02:54:59.880 | so something 600 times smaller than DeepSeq,
02:55:02.400 | you can boost its grade school math scores
02:55:04.840 | very directly with a small amount of this training.
02:55:07.600 | So it's not to say that this is coming soon.
02:55:10.480 | Setting up the verification domains is extremely hard
02:55:13.160 | and there's a lot of nuance in this,
02:55:15.340 | but there are some basic things that we have seen before
02:55:18.120 | where it's like, it's at least expectable
02:55:21.280 | that there's a domain and there's a chance that this works.
02:55:23.760 | - All right, so we have fun things happening in real time.
02:55:25.920 | This is a good opportunity to talk
02:55:27.400 | about other reasoning models, O1, O3.
02:55:31.760 | Just now OpenAI, as perhaps expected, released O3 mini.
02:55:36.760 | What are we expecting from the different flavors?
02:55:41.040 | Can you just lay out the different flavors
02:55:43.000 | of the O models and from Gemini, the reasoning model?
02:55:47.360 | - Something I would say about these reasoning models
02:55:49.280 | is we talked a lot about reasoning training
02:55:51.480 | on math and code.
02:55:52.820 | And what is done is that you have the base model
02:55:55.120 | we've talked about a lot on the internet.
02:55:56.640 | You do this large-scale reasoning training
02:55:58.760 | with reinforcement learning.
02:56:00.320 | And then what the DeepSeq paper detailed in this R1 paper,
02:56:04.560 | which for me is one of the big open questions
02:56:07.000 | on how do you do this, is that they did reasoning heavy,
02:56:10.640 | but very standard post-training techniques
02:56:13.320 | after the large-scale reasoning RL.
02:56:15.160 | So they did the same things
02:56:16.440 | with a form of instruction tuning
02:56:18.720 | through rejection sampling,
02:56:19.960 | which is essentially heavily filtered instruction tuning
02:56:22.880 | with some reward models.
02:56:23.960 | And then they did this RLHF, but they made it math heavy.
02:56:27.540 | So some of this transfer,

03:08:42.180 | right?
03:08:43.460 | And so Chain of Thought is one thing where it's able,
03:08:45.300 | it's one chain, it backtracks, goes back and forth,
03:08:48.140 | but how they solved the ArcAGI challenge
03:08:50.740 | was not just the Chain of Thought.
03:08:53.140 | It was also sampling many times,
03:08:55.100 | i.e. running them in parallel, and then selecting.
03:08:58.100 | - Is running in parallel actually Search?
03:09:00.300 | 'Cause I don't know if we have the full information
03:09:02.180 | on how O1 Pro works.
03:09:03.300 | So I don't have enough information
03:09:05.380 | to confidently say that it is Search.
03:09:07.100 | - It is parallel samples.
03:09:08.620 | - Yeah, and then what? - And it selects something.
03:09:10.340 | - And we don't know what the selection function is.
03:09:12.180 | The reason why we're debating
03:09:13.860 | is because since O1 was announced,
03:09:16.180 | there's been a lot of interest in techniques
03:09:17.740 | called Monte Carlo Tree Search,
03:09:18.980 | which is where you will break down the Chain of Thought
03:09:21.580 | into intermediate steps.
03:09:22.780 | We haven't defined Chain of Thought.
03:09:24.580 | Chain of Thought is from a paper from years ago
03:09:27.340 | where you introduce the idea to ask a language model
03:09:29.980 | that at the time was much less easy to use.
03:09:32.740 | You would say, "Let's verify step-by-step,"
03:09:34.900 | and it would induce the model
03:09:36.100 | to do this bulleted list of steps.
03:09:38.220 | Chain of Thought is now almost a default in models,
03:09:41.060 | where if you ask it a math question,
03:09:42.300 | you don't need to tell it to think step-by-step.
03:09:44.500 | And the idea with Monte Carlo Tree Search
03:09:46.980 | is that you would take an intermediate point in that chain,
03:09:49.980 | do some sort of expansion, spend more compute,
03:09:52.340 | and then just select the right one.
03:09:53.780 | That's like a very complex form of Search
03:09:55.500 | that has been used in things like Mu0 and AlphaZero.
03:09:58.700 | Potentially, I know Mu0 does this.
03:10:00.940 | - Another form of Search is just asking
03:10:02.900 | five different people and then taking the majority answer.
03:10:05.180 | - Yes.
03:10:06.020 | - There's a variety of, it could be complicated,
03:10:08.740 | it could be simple.
03:10:09.980 | We don't know what it is,
03:10:10.900 | just that they are not just issuing
03:10:13.100 | one Chain of Thought in sequence.
03:10:15.220 | They're launching many in parallel.
03:10:17.300 | And in the Arc AGI, they launched 1,000 in parallel
03:10:20.500 | for the one that really shocked everyone,
03:10:23.060 | that beat the benchmark,
03:10:24.020 | was they would launch 1,000 in parallel,
03:10:26.340 | and then they would get the right answer
03:10:27.580 | like 80% of the time or 70% of the time, 90 maybe even.
03:10:30.540 | Whereas if they just launched one,
03:10:32.420 | it was like 30%.
03:10:33.700 | - There are many extensions to this.
03:10:35.540 | I would say the simplest one
03:10:36.980 | is that our language models to date
03:10:39.020 | have been designed to give the right answer
03:10:41.620 | the highest percentage of the time in one response.
03:10:44.860 | And we are now opening the door
03:10:46.300 | to different ways of running inference on our models,
03:10:49.500 | in which we need to re-evaluate
03:10:51.100 | many parts of the training process,

03:12:52.060 | oh my God, they made it so cheap.

03:12:55.900 | they're not below the trend line, first of all,
03:12:57.780 | and at least for GPT-3, right?

03:13:20.260 | to new generations or ASICs,

03:13:24.740 | down and down and down and down.

03:13:30.780 | to create a task and then pick from one of them,

03:13:39.100 | Maybe it doesn't, 'cause it's too complicated
03:13:40.460 | to actually scale, like who knows?
03:13:42.260 | Bitter lesson, right?
03:13:43.820 | The question is, I think, when, not if,
03:13:47.980 | because the rate of progress is so fast, right?
03:13:51.700 | Nine months ago, Dario said nine months ago
03:13:55.220 | the cost to train and inference was this, right?
03:13:57.660 | And now we're much better than this, right?

03:14:03.800 | which was also roughly $60 per million tokens
03:14:06.860 | when it launched, has already fallen to $2 or so, right?
03:14:11.340 | And we're gonna get it down to cents, probably,
