03:17:48.980 | for a demo and it was not very easy.
03:17:51.100 | - So for people who don't know, Javon's paradox
03:17:53.260 | is when, you know, the efficiency goes up,
03:17:58.180 | somehow magically, counterintuitively,
03:18:00.780 | the total resource consumption goes up as well.
03:18:03.020 | - Right, and semiconductors is, you know,
03:18:04.820 | we're at 50 years of Moore's law.
03:18:07.260 | Every two years, half the cost, double the transistors.
03:18:09.860 | Just like clockwork, and it's slowed down obviously,
03:18:11.540 | but like the semiconductor industry
03:18:13.580 | has gone up the whole time, right?

03:18:16.180 | There's obviously cycles and stuff
03:18:17.540 | and I don't expect AI to be any different, right?
03:18:19.500 | There's gonna be ebbs and flows, but this is,
03:18:22.140 | in AI, it's just playing out at an insane timescale, right?
03:18:24.980 | It was 2X every two years.
03:18:26.980 | This is 1200X in like three years, right?
03:18:29.860 | So it's like the scale of improvement
03:18:32.180 | that is like hard to wrap your head around.
03:18:34.580 | - Yeah, I was confused because I, to me,

03:26:23.880 | - We've talked a lot about training language models.
03:26:26.160 | They are trained on text.
03:26:27.480 | In post-training, you're trying to train
03:26:29.600 | on very high-quality text
03:26:30.920 | that you want the model to match the features of,
03:26:33.040 | or if you're using RL,
03:26:34.440 | you're letting the model find its own thing.
03:26:36.040 | But for supervised fine-tuning, for preference data,
03:26:38.780 | you need to have some completions
03:26:40.680 | of what the model is trying to learn to imitate.
03:26:42.960 | And what you do there is, instead of a human data,
03:26:46.720 | or instead of the model you're currently training,
03:26:49.260 | you take completions from a different,
03:26:51.180 | normally more powerful model.
03:26:53.160 | I think there's rumors that these big models
03:26:56.280 | that people are waiting for,
03:26:57.780 | these GPT-5s of the world,
03:26:59.320 | the CLAWD-3 opuses of the world,

03:27:04.320 | at OpenAI. - There's also
03:27:05.160 | public examples, right?

03:27:09.660 | but they used 405(b) as a reward model
03:27:12.240 | for 70(b) in their LLAMA 3.2 and 3.3.
03:27:15.060 | - This is all the same topic.
03:27:16.720 | - So is this ethical, is this legal?

03:27:24.920 | say OpenAI says that there's evidence
03:27:28.080 | that China's DeepSeek used its model to train competitor?
03:27:31.680 | - This is a long, at least in the academic side
03:27:34.620 | and research side, it has a long history
03:27:35.960 | 'cause you're trying to interpret OpenAI's rule.
03:27:38.080 | OpenAI's terms of service say
03:27:40.400 | that you cannot build a competitor
03:27:41.960 | with outputs from their model.
03:27:43.400 | Terms of service are different than a license,
03:27:45.100 | which are essentially a contract between organizations.
03:27:48.080 | So if you have a terms of service on OpenAI's account,
03:27:50.420 | if I violate it, OpenAI can cancel my account.
03:27:53.100 | This is very different than like a license
03:27:54.760 | that says how you could use a downstream artifact.
03:27:56.960 | So a lot of it hinges on a word
03:27:58.320 | that is very unclear in the AI space,
03:28:00.080 | which is what is a competitor.
03:28:01.480 | - And then the ethical aspect of it is like,
03:28:04.600 | why is it unethical for me to train on your model
03:28:07.200 | when you can train on the internet's text?
03:28:09.120 | - Yeah. - Right?
03:28:10.040 | - So there's a bit of a hypocrisy
03:28:11.800 | because OpenAI and potentially most of the companies
03:28:16.800 | trained on the internet's text without permission.

03:28:25.280 | and then I upload it somewhere

03:28:28.420 | and the link has been broken.
03:28:30.160 | Like they're not under the same terms of service contract.
03:28:32.920 | - This is why-- - There's a lot of hypocrisy.
03:28:34.800 | There's a lot of link to be discovered details
03:28:37.440 | that don't make a lot of sense.
03:28:38.560 | - This is why a lot of models today,
03:28:40.600 | even if they train on zero OpenAI data,

03:28:47.540 | Because there's so much copy paste
03:28:49.420 | of like OpenAI outputs from that on the internet
03:28:52.200 | that you just weren't able to filter it out.
03:28:53.720 | And there was nothing in the RL
03:28:55.640 | where they implemented like hey,
03:28:57.800 | or post-training or SFT, whatever that says,
03:28:59.720 | "Hey, I'm actually a model by Allen Institute
03:29:02.760 | instead of OpenAI." - We have to do this.
03:29:04.760 | We serve a demo.

03:44:25.400 | - Everyone is doing this, right?
03:44:26.720 | Everyone is doing this, right?

03:44:33.600 | And then they're building this massive data center.

03:45:22.440 | You don't get 10X better model, right?
03:45:24.040 | You get a diminishing returns, but also
03:45:25.920 | you get efficiency improvements.
03:45:27.120 | So you bend the curve, right?
03:45:28.800 | And these scale of data centers are doing,

03:45:32.600 | a lot of like havoc on the network, right?

03:45:54.960 | than actually generating it, right?

03:46:01.160 | and like re-ramping on a natural gas plant
03:46:03.440 | or even a coal plant is like easy enough to do,
03:46:05.160 | but like transmitting the power is really hard.

03:46:11.520 | than it costs to generate it.
03:46:12.800 | Which is like, you know, there's all sorts
03:46:14.280 | of like second order effects that are insane here.
03:46:16.640 | - Can the power grid support this kind of growth?

03:50:22.200 | which are just like glossed over.
03:50:24.000 | - Yeah.
03:50:25.160 | - But I think like one story that maybe is like
03:50:27.960 | exemplifies how insane this stuff is,
03:50:30.320 | is when you're training, right?
03:50:33.080 | You're always doing, you're running through the model
03:50:35.600 | a bunch, right, in the most simplistic terms,
03:50:37.000 | running through the model a bunch,
03:50:38.480 | and then you're gonna exchange everything
03:50:41.520 | and synchronize the weights, right?
03:50:43.040 | So you'll do a step.
03:50:44.120 | This is like a step in model training, right?
03:50:45.720 | And every step your loss goes down, hopefully.
03:50:47.360 | And it doesn't always, but in the simplest terms,
03:50:50.240 | you'll be computing a lot and then you'll exchange, right?
03:50:52.640 | The interesting thing is GPU power is most of it.
03:50:54.560 | Networking power is some, but it's a lot less.
03:50:56.400 | But so while you're computing,
03:50:57.800 | your power for your GPUs is here.
03:50:59.360 | But then when you're exchanging weights,
03:51:01.280 | if you're not able to overlap communications
03:51:03.160 | and compute perfectly, there may be a time period
03:51:05.300 | where your GPUs are just idle and you're exchanging weights
03:51:08.080 | and you're like, hey, the model's updating.
03:51:09.600 | So you're exchanging the gradients,
03:51:10.680 | you do the model update, and then you start training again.
03:51:13.520 | So the power goes, right?
03:51:15.760 | And it's super spiky.
03:51:17.120 | And so funnily enough, right?
03:51:18.480 | Like this, when you talk about the scale
03:51:20.760 | of data center power, right?
03:51:22.040 | You can blow stuff up so easily.
03:51:23.680 | And so Meta actually has accidentally
03:51:27.520 | open upstream something to code in PyTorch,
03:51:30.400 | where they added an operator.
03:51:31.960 | And I kid you not, whoever made this,
03:51:33.320 | like, I wanna hug the guy because it says,
03:51:35.120 | says PyTorch, it's like PyTorch.powerplant, no blow up.
03:51:39.120 | Equals zero or equal one.
03:51:41.520 | And what it does, what it does is amazing, right?
03:51:44.160 | Either, you know, when you're exchanging the weights,
03:51:46.520 | the GPU will just compute fake numbers.
03:51:48.240 | So the power doesn't spike too much.
03:51:49.880 | And so then the power plants don't blow up
03:51:51.400 | because the transient spikes, like screw stuff up.
03:51:54.240 | - Well, that makes sense.
03:51:55.080 | I mean, you have to do that kind of thing.
03:51:56.600 | You have to make sure they're not idle, yeah.
03:51:59.200 | - And Elon's solution was like,
03:52:00.380 | let me throw a bunch of Tesla mega packs
03:52:01.760 | and a few other things, right?
03:52:03.280 | Everyone has different solutions,
03:52:04.600 | but like Meta's at least was publicly and openly known,
03:52:07.240 | which is just like, set this operator.
03:52:09.240 | And what this operator does is it just makes
03:52:11.040 | the GPUs compute nothing so that the power doesn't spike.
03:52:14.360 | - But that just tells you how much power you're working with.
03:52:17.040 | I mean, it's insane.
03:52:18.080 | It's insane.

03:53:18.800 | and that required a lot of stuff, right?

03:53:31.480 | The container.
03:53:32.300 | But really those are water chillers.
03:53:33.320 | And he has like 90 of those water chillers
03:53:35.080 | just sitting outside, 90 different containers, right?
03:53:37.440 | With the water, you know, like chill the water,
03:53:39.440 | bring it back to the data center,
03:53:40.880 | and then you distribute it to all the chips,
03:53:42.760 | pull all the heat out and then send it back, right?
03:53:44.680 | And this is both a way to cool the chips,
03:53:47.720 | but also as an efficiency thing, all right?
03:53:49.800 | And going back to that like sort of three vector thing,
03:53:52.040 | right, there is memory bandwidth flops and interconnect.
03:53:56.720 | The closer the chips are together,
03:53:58.120 | the easier it is to do high speed interconnects, right?
03:54:02.280 | And so this is also like a reason
03:54:04.760 | why you're gonna go water cooling
03:54:05.800 | is because you can just put the chips
03:54:07.600 | right next to each other
03:54:08.560 | and therefore get higher speed connectivity.

03:56:16.520 | - So what's the idea with these clusters?

03:56:45.940 | Because the mega clusters, right?

03:56:50.680 | Because that's where all of my GPUs are co-located,
03:56:52.760 | where I can put them at a super high networking speed
03:56:55.480 | connected together, right?
03:56:56.720 | Because that's what you need for training.
03:56:58.240 | Now, with pre-training, this is the old scale, right?
03:57:00.700 | You could, you would increase parameters.
03:57:02.160 | You didn't increase data, model gets better.
03:57:05.040 | That doesn't apply anymore,
03:57:06.760 | because there's not much more data
03:57:08.180 | in the pre-training side, right?
03:57:10.200 | Yes, there's video and audio and image
03:57:11.800 | that has not been fully taken advantage of.
03:57:13.860 | So there's a lot more scaling,
03:57:14.880 | but a lot of people like, have transcript,
03:57:17.440 | taken transcripts of YouTube videos.
03:57:18.880 | And that gets you a lot of the data.
03:57:20.120 | It doesn't get you all of the learning value
03:57:21.520 | out of the video and image data.
03:57:22.760 | But there's still scaling to be done on pre-training.
03:57:26.440 | But this post-training world
03:57:27.860 | is where all the flops are gonna be spent, right?
03:57:29.960 | The model is gonna play with itself.
03:57:31.240 | It's gonna self-play.
03:57:32.080 | It's gonna do verifiable tasks.
03:57:33.400 | It's gonna do computer use in sandboxes.
03:57:36.040 | It might even do like simulated robotics things, right?
03:57:38.800 | Like all of these things are gonna be environments
03:57:41.460 | where compute is spent in quote-unquote post-training.
03:57:44.660 | But I think it's gonna be good.
03:57:46.400 | We're gonna drop the post from post-training.
03:57:48.840 | - Yeah, wow. - It's gonna be pre-training
03:57:49.680 | and it's gonna be training, I think.
03:57:51.080 | - The return of the king. - At some point.
03:57:53.880 | Because for the bulk of the last few years,
03:57:57.400 | pre-training has dwarfed post-training.
03:58:00.140 | But with these verifiable methods,
03:58:01.720 | especially ones that scale really potentially infinitely,
03:58:05.480 | like computer use and robotics,
03:58:06.680 | not just math and coding, right?
03:58:08.080 | Where you can verify what's happening.
03:58:09.560 | Those infinitely verifiable tasks,
03:58:11.280 | it seems you can spend as much compute as you want on them.
03:58:13.440 | - Especially at the context length increase.
03:58:15.020 | 'Cause at the end of pre-training
03:58:16.560 | is when you increase the context length for these models.
03:58:19.120 | And we've talked earlier in the conversation
03:58:21.480 | about how the context length,
03:58:23.000 | when you have a long input,
03:58:24.280 | is much easier to manage than output.
03:58:26.000 | And a lot of these post-training and reasoning techniques
03:58:28.080 | rely on a ton of sampling
03:58:30.560 | and it's becoming increasingly long context.
03:58:32.960 | So it's just like you're,
03:58:34.480 | effectively your compute efficiency goes down.
03:58:36.920 | I don't, I think FLOPS is the standard
03:58:39.880 | for how you measure it.
03:58:40.880 | But with RL and you have to do all these things
03:58:43.400 | where you move your weights around
03:58:45.640 | in a different way than at pre-training
03:58:47.640 | and just generation,
03:58:49.360 | it's going to become less efficient
03:58:51.520 | and FLOPS is gonna be less of a useful term.
03:58:53.800 | And then as the infrastructure gets better,
03:58:55.240 | it's probably gonna go back to FLOPS.
03:58:57.000 | - So all of the things we've been talking about
03:58:59.080 | is most likely going to be NVIDIA, right?
03:59:01.960 | Is there any competitors?
03:59:03.400 | - Google, I kind of ignored them.
03:59:05.540 | - Yeah, what's the story with TPU?
03:59:08.040 | What's the story with TPU?
03:59:09.400 | Like what's the-
03:59:10.600 | - TPU is awesome, right?
03:59:12.160 | It's great.

04:29:24.920 | I mean, OpenAI probably has them internally
04:29:26.640 | to train these things.
04:29:27.480 | It's the same as DeepMind's robotics team for years
04:29:29.720 | has had clusters for robotics
04:29:31.880 | where you interact with robots fully remotely.
04:29:34.620 | They just have a lab in London and you send tasks to it,
04:29:37.480 | arrange the blocks and you do this research.
04:29:39.800 | Obviously there's techs there that fix stuff,
04:29:42.240 | but we've turned these cranks of automation before.
04:29:46.480 | You go from sandbox to progress
04:29:48.320 | and then you add one more domain at a time and generalize.
04:29:51.880 | I think in the history of NLP and language processing,
04:29:55.360 | instruction tuning and tasks per language model
04:29:57.760 | used to be like one language model did one task.
04:30:00.160 | And then in the instruction tuning literature,
04:30:01.840 | there's this point where you start adding more
04:30:03.680 | and more tasks together,
04:30:05.240 | where it just starts to generalize to every task.
04:30:07.520 | And we don't know where on this curve we are.
04:30:09.000 | I think for reasoning with this RL and verifiable domains,
04:30:11.320 | we're early, but we don't know where the point is
04:30:14.120 | where you just start training on enough domains
04:30:16.600 | and poof, like more domains just start working
04:30:19.360 | and you've crossed the generalization barrier.
04:30:22.000 | - Well, what do you think about the programming context?
04:30:24.800 | So software engineering, that's where I personally,
04:30:30.040 | and I know a lot of people interact with AI the most.

04:37:58.280 | - Yeah, this is the-- - Tulu.
04:38:00.200 | - I'll explain what a Tulu is.
04:38:01.520 | A Tulu is a hybrid camel when you breed a dromedary
04:38:04.160 | with a Bacchurian camel.
04:38:06.480 | Back in the early days after ChatGPT,
04:38:08.480 | there was a big wave of models coming out,
04:38:10.800 | like Alpaca, Vicuna, et cetera,
04:38:12.240 | that were all named after various mammalian species.
04:38:15.920 | So Tulu, the brand is multiple years old,
04:38:18.440 | which comes from that, and we've been playing
04:38:22.480 | at the frontiers of post-training with open source code.
04:38:25.600 | And this first part of this release was in the fall,
04:38:28.880 | where we built on Lama's open weight models,
04:38:33.800 | and then we add in our fully open code,
04:38:35.880 | our fully open data.
04:38:37.240 | There's a popular benchmark that is Chatbot Arena,
04:38:40.640 | and that's generally the metric
04:38:42.360 | by which how these chat models are evaluated,
04:38:44.800 | and it's humans compare random models
04:38:47.340 | from different organizations.
04:38:48.760 | And if you looked at the leaderboard in November or December,
04:38:51.600 | among the top 60 models from 10s to 20s of organizations,
04:38:55.680 | none of them had open code or data for just post-training.
04:38:58.600 | Among that, even fewer or none have pre-training data
04:39:01.160 | and code available, but it's like post-training
04:39:03.120 | is much more accessible at this time.
04:39:04.360 | It's still pretty cheap and you can do it.
04:39:06.240 | And the thing is like, how high can we push this number
04:39:08.560 | where people have access to all the code and data?
04:39:11.340 | So that's kind of the motivation of the project.
04:39:12.880 | We draw on lessons from Lama.
04:39:14.360 | NVIDIA had a Nemotron model where the recipe
04:39:17.520 | for their post-training was fairly open with some data,
04:39:20.560 | and a paper, and it's putting all these together
04:39:23.020 | to try to create a recipe that people can fine-tune models
04:39:26.040 | like GPT-4 to their domain.
04:39:27.880 | - So to be clear, in the case of Tulu,
04:39:30.640 | maybe you can talk about Alma too,
04:39:32.040 | but in the case of Tulu, you're taking Lama 3.405b.
04:39:35.960 | - Tulu has been a series of recipes for post-training.
04:39:41.400 | So we've done multiple models over years.
04:39:43.880 | - And so you're open sourcing everything.
04:39:46.720 | - Yeah, if you start with an open weight-based model,
04:39:49.080 | the whole model technically is an open source
04:39:51.600 | 'cause you don't know what Lama put into it,

04:39:55.880 | but it's just getting parts of the pipeline
04:39:58.400 | where people can zoom in and customize.

04:40:01.880 | they're like, "Okay, I can take this post-training
04:40:03.920 | "and try to apply it to my domain."

04:40:09.800 | with verifiable domain rewards, RLVR,
04:40:13.160 | kind of similar to RLHF, and we've applied it to map.

04:40:40.400 | that you're evaluating, we're researchers.

04:40:49.520 | it's easier to elicit powerful capabilities

04:43:38.920 | - This goes very back to license discussion.

04:43:44.000 | So it's like the first time that we've had

04:44:30.960 | and they removed that for scale.

04:44:36.960 | or like that's the type of thing that is forbidden there,
04:44:39.680 | but that's enough from an open source background
04:44:42.040 | to say it's not open source license.
04:44:43.440 | And also the LLAMA license has this horrible thing
04:44:45.880 | where you have to name your model LLAMA
04:44:48.520 | if you touch it to the LLAMA model.
04:44:50.920 | So it's like the branding thing.
04:44:52.040 | So if a company uses LLAMA,
04:44:53.560 | technically the license says that they should say
04:44:55.480 | built with LLAMA at the bottom of their application.
04:44:57.600 | And from like a marketing perspective, that just hurts.
04:45:00.200 | Like I can suck it up as a researcher.
04:45:01.880 | I'm like, oh, it's fine.
04:45:02.920 | Like it says LLAMA dash on all of our materials
04:45:06.280 | for this release.

04:45:08.920 | which is we don't know DeepSeek R1's data.

04:45:15.120 | and pretend it's mine,
04:45:15.960 | but I can do this with the Chinese model.
04:45:17.680 | - Yeah. - Hell yeah.
04:45:18.520 | (both laughing)
04:45:20.280 | - That's what I'm saying.
04:45:21.880 | And that's why it's like,
04:45:22.920 | we want this whole open language models thing,
04:45:26.040 | the Olmo thing, is to try to keep the model
04:45:28.640 | where everything is open with the data
04:45:30.440 | as close to the frontier as possible.
04:45:31.920 | So we're compute constrained, we're personnel constrained.
04:45:34.840 | We rely on getting insights from people,
04:45:37.360 | like John Shulman tells us to do RL on outputs.
04:45:39.920 | Like we can make these big jumps,
04:45:41.560 | but it just takes a long time
04:45:43.240 | to push the frontier of open source.
04:45:44.760 | And fundamentally, I would say that that's because
04:45:48.160 | open source AI does not have the same feedback loops
04:45:50.840 | as open source software.
04:45:51.880 | We talked about open source software for security.
04:45:54.480 | Also, it's just because you build something once
04:45:56.800 | and you can reuse it.
04:45:57.840 | If you go into a new company, there's so many benefits.
04:46:00.560 | But if you open source a language model,
04:46:02.680 | you have this data sitting around,
04:46:04.280 | you have this training code.
04:46:05.600 | It's not like that easy for someone to come
04:46:08.080 | and build on and improve,
04:46:09.080 | 'cause you need to spend a lot on compute,
04:46:10.440 | you need to have expertise.
04:46:12.040 | So until there are feedback loops of open source AI,
04:46:15.200 | it seems like mostly an ideological mission.
04:46:18.200 | People like Mark Zuckerberg,
04:46:19.200 | which is like America needs this.
04:46:20.920 | And I agree with him,

04:46:27.040 | we need to capitalize and build this ecosystem
04:46:29.160 | around what benefits do you get
04:46:31.280 | from seeing the language model data.

04:46:36.760 | where you can look at an Olmo model in a query
